A current dispatch tiy the ACP
from Columbus reports that cooperative purchase of supplies by fraternities and sororities at the Ohio
State University saved them 16% on
$90,000 worth of provisions during
the last year. Forty-six of the 58
fraternities now have "A" credit ratings. When the auditing division was
established on its.present basis four
years ago, fraternities 'owed creditors approximately $65,000. This has
now been reduced to $15,000. We
don't have any statistics on the credit
rating- of lippkiae. fraternities, but
'certainly they don't have any trouble
reducing debts below $15,000 without
the need of cooperative purchases.

Hopkins Booters
Battle Maryland
Tomorrow, the Hopkins booters
travel to College Park to meet the
Terps in a soccer clash.
Hopkins, to date, has topped Gettysburg 2-1 and Towson State Teachers 1-0. The only contest the Lyonsmen have dropped was to Western
Maryland in the season opener by a
4-2 count.
In their only battle last year, the
Blue Jays downed the Terps, 2-1.
Maryland has been gunning for Hopkins in an attempt to revenge that
defeat.
Strength Offense
To date, Hopkins rivals have tallied only five goals. Four of these
were made by Western Maryland.
Mader this condition, the Hopkins offense is being stressed by Coach
Lyons.
Briggs and Braysham have been
the main offensive threats with Price,
Taragin, and Phillips helping out.
At the goalie position, Maryland
will find Romanofsky. The defense
will be Captain Gough and Stout
at the fullback positions.
Hartke Back
Although injured in the Towson
game, Hartke is expected to return
to his center half position. Kephart
and Hooper will perform on Hartke'S
flank.
Following the Maryland clash, the
soccer team meets Towson in a return match.

Manager Lipnick requests that all
interested attend this meeting.

HITHER AND YONJ

FRAT STANDINGS

By LEN RUBINGER
Last week's hair-breadth gridiron victory. gave our Blue Jays their
second consecutive triumph over Haverford—one of the two colleges with
whom we seem destined to establish new traditional rivalries.
it has been interesting to observe, these past few years, the gradual
cementing and shaping of our relationships with Haverford and Swarthmore,
institutions which, between themselves, enjoy a competition,easily as intense
and bitter as caws with St. Johns. Perhaps, as a result of our newly established sports policy—a plan which had been in the process of development for
a number of years, we have been influenced in our scheduling of teams more
by scholastic reputations than by athletic abilities. Hence our present leaning
toward the Pennsylvania schools.
There is no doubt in anyone's mind that Haverford and Swarthmore
are more our scholastic equals than any of the establishments with whom
we have had dealings in recent years. And now it appears that those same
schools are more our athletic „equals than some of our past opponents have
proved to be. Where-once we Pound ourselves anxiously awaiting contests
with such teams as Maryland and Washington, now we discover that our
competition with the Terps has almost entirely ceased, while that with
Washington College is on the way to depletion.
Instead we are aware of the increasing interest and excitement evident
in preparation for games with our new Philadelphia rivals. Our pigskin representatives are at present, besides rejoicing over their latest football experience, anticipating their coming battle with the maroon-clad warriors of
Swarthmore. The fact that they cannot'forget last year's 40-19 defeat up
at the Swarthmore field is further proof of their newly acquired spirit.
By the way, in reviewing that mad football,scramble of last year, it is
well to be reminded that the two squads were not as far apart as the score
indicates. Swarthmore's forty points were run up in a moment of our weakness— so to speak; and during the second pair, in which our heroes managed
to find themselves, Swarthmore not only returned nineteen of her points, but
deposited at least twe or three gallons of cold sweat as well.
The next few years will see whether there will be a shift in our traditional attachments. It is the opinion of the writer that more is to be gotten
out of our coanections with Haverford and Swarthmore, than with the other
teams with which sye carry out our athletic skirmishes.

—Johns Hopkins will never pay nor accept guarantees, will finance its own
trips away and expect visiting teams to do the same.

There has been a great deal said
about the glory that is, and was
the Hopkins, along athletic lines, I
mean. Once again J. H. U. is in the
limelight because of her new "free
gate" policy.
It seems to me—and I hope you
don't mind—that the Hopkins Board
of Control in this matter, knows how
to take advantage of opportunities.
Years ago, when we had a good
team

in comparison to the other
schools, there was no talk of "free
gate." Now the other schools have

forged

ahead
athleticly, leaving
J. H. U. to muddle about for some six
or seven years until an idea strikes.

And what an idea!! One that upholds all that is fair and square to
the college man--Intramurals for all
and all varsity games for nothing!
Not a joker in the deck!
Liberal collegiate papers in other
schools, sports editors east and west,
and expectant observers laud the
Hopkins—It's a New Deal in Sports!
The point is, suppose tke....licopirrns
had had a team or a number of
teams. comparing in size, strength,
and record, with teams such as Pitt,
L.S.U., etc. What with the financial
slump the schoo,1 was in I wonder
if a "free gate" would have been
proposed then? I wonder??
—Analyzer

the last year. Forty-six of the 58
fraternities now have "A" credit ratings. When the auditing division was

years ago, fraternities 'owed creditors approximately $65,000. This has
now been reduced to $15,000. We
don't have any statistics on the credit
rating- of lippkiae. fraternities, but
'certainly they don't have any trouble
reducing debts below $15,000 without
the need of cooperative purchases.

Hopkins Booters
Battle Maryland
Tomorrow, the Hopkins booters
travel to College Park to meet the
Terps in a soccer clash.
Hopkins, to date, has topped Gettysburg 2-1 and Towson State Teachers 1-0. The only contest the Lyonsmen have dropped was to Western
Maryland in the season opener by a
4-2 count.
In their only battle last year, the
Blue Jays downed the Terps, 2-1.
Maryland has been gunning for Hopkins in an attempt to revenge that
defeat.
Strength Offense
To date, Hopkins rivals have tallied only five goals. Four of these
were made by Western Maryland.
Mader this condition, the Hopkins offense is being stressed by Coach
Lyons.
Briggs and Braysham have been
the main offensive threats with Price,
Taragin, and Phillips helping out.
At the goalie position, Maryland
will find Romanofsky. The defense
will be Captain Gough and Stout
at the fullback positions.
Hartke Back
Although injured in the Towson
game, Hartke is expected to return
to his center half position. Kephart
and Hooper will perform on Hartke'S
flank.
Following the Maryland clash, the
soccer team meets Towson in a return match.

Manager Lipnick requests that all
interested attend this meeting.

HITHER AND YONJ

FRAT STANDINGS

By LEN RUBINGER
Last week's hair-breadth gridiron victory. gave our Blue Jays their
second consecutive triumph over Haverford—one of the two colleges with
whom we seem destined to establish new traditional rivalries.
it has been interesting to observe, these past few years, the gradual
cementing and shaping of our relationships with Haverford and Swarthmore,
institutions which, between themselves, enjoy a competition,easily as intense
and bitter as caws with St. Johns. Perhaps, as a result of our newly established sports policy—a plan which had been in the process of development for
a number of years, we have been influenced in our scheduling of teams more
by scholastic reputations than by athletic abilities. Hence our present leaning
toward the Pennsylvania schools.
There is no doubt in anyone's mind that Haverford and Swarthmore
are more our scholastic equals than any of the establishments with whom
we have had dealings in recent years. And now it appears that those same
schools are more our athletic „equals than some of our past opponents have
proved to be. Where-once we Pound ourselves anxiously awaiting contests
with such teams as Maryland and Washington, now we discover that our
competition with the Terps has almost entirely ceased, while that with
Washington College is on the way to depletion.
Instead we are aware of the increasing interest and excitement evident
in preparation for games with our new Philadelphia rivals. Our pigskin representatives are at present, besides rejoicing over their latest football experience, anticipating their coming battle with the maroon-clad warriors of
Swarthmore. The fact that they cannot'forget last year's 40-19 defeat up
at the Swarthmore field is further proof of their newly acquired spirit.
By the way, in reviewing that mad football,scramble of last year, it is
well to be reminded that the two squads were not as far apart as the score
indicates. Swarthmore's forty points were run up in a moment of our weakness— so to speak; and during the second pair, in which our heroes managed
to find themselves, Swarthmore not only returned nineteen of her points, but
deposited at least twe or three gallons of cold sweat as well.
The next few years will see whether there will be a shift in our traditional attachments. It is the opinion of the writer that more is to be gotten
out of our coanections with Haverford and Swarthmore, than with the other
teams with which sye carry out our athletic skirmishes.

There has been a great deal said
about the glory that is, and was
the Hopkins, along athletic lines, I
mean. Once again J. H. U. is in the
limelight because of her new "free
gate" policy.
It seems to me—and I hope you
don't mind—that the Hopkins Board
of Control in this matter, knows how
to take advantage of opportunities.
Years ago, when we had a good
team

in comparison to the other
schools, there was no talk of "free
gate." Now the other schools have

forged

ahead
athleticly, leaving
J. H. U. to muddle about for some six
or seven years until an idea strikes.

And what an idea!! One that upholds all that is fair and square to
the college man--Intramurals for all
and all varsity games for nothing!
Not a joker in the deck!
Liberal collegiate papers in other
schools, sports editors east and west,
and expectant observers laud the
Hopkins—It's a New Deal in Sports!
The point is, suppose tke....licopirrns
had had a team or a number of
teams. comparing in size, strength,
and record, with teams such as Pitt,
L.S.U., etc. What with the financial
slump the schoo,1 was in I wonder
if a "free gate" would have been
proposed then? I wonder??
—Analyzer
